  5766. So, I would take about 2 hours to put on a set of gelish only for it to look less than desireable and it would start falling off in whole pieces the next day.
  5767. definitely cuts the time in half and its big so its twice as fast
  5768. I'll try to post pictures of how my nails looked after doing this - I FINALLY have nails that grow out, and without the big \\"ridge\\" that the old-style acrylic nails left when growing out!uick reply to my questions if I'm not sure about how to use a product , and they replied right away.
  5769. As other reviewers have mentioned, it is large enough for both hands (or feet) to dry at the same time.
  5770. A little bigger than what i expected but its worth the money.
  5771. this light was much larger than I had envisioned, so storage of it was little bit harder than I expected for home use.
  5772. The opening is wide enough to cure two hands or feet together, but if working alone one would typically paint one hand, cure it under the light, then paint the other hand.
  5773. I can take my time, do one hand at a time (although this is certainly large enough to do both hands at the same time) and in less time than what I would spend at a salon, my nails are done to my liking!
  5774. Since I always use a lightly pink clear color it is a piece of cake.

  6. I used to go to the nail salon every 2 weeks... In an effort to save money I picked up this machine and nail polish from Candy Lover.<br />1. The machine is way larger than in the salon which is good because doing your nails yourself allows you to dry both hands at the same time.<br />3. It takes so much longer to dry!!!!<br /><br />Its been an hour and my nails are still drying! I never write reviews but I'm so bored waiting for my toes to dry that I decide to make use of this time. My finger nails are still wet so I'm being super careful.<br /><br />I accidentally got some fuzz on my thumb; I have no idea where it came from, so that finger is ruined - but you know what? For the price of this machine, it's less than how much I pay+ tip in the salon.<br /><br />Do I love it? NOPE! But I'm going to save money and still get the look. I just have to be ridiculously patient.<br /><br />If you are not patient, you will end up chucking this thing out the window.<br /><br />If you're trying to save but still look fabulous, you'll be fine.<br /><br />I'm not sure how long I will last but if I use this thing and the polish just one more time, I will have saved money on the two mani and pedis I would have paid for, you decide if it's worth your 2 1/2 hours. Going on 3...<br /><br />*So far my toes have sat on the 300SEC setting + fan, 11 times.

  22. It's a bit difficult to get it right at first but I've just used it one time. If you follow the other girls reviews as I did they are dead on. One thing I didn't give that much consideration was if you use to much it pools around the edges and you cannot wipe it off. Make sure your brush is completely not to loaded dripping. Wipe it off on the edge of the bottle. ESPECIALLY THE base COAT. It is the coat by which all the other coats will be decided. Believe me this stuff will last forever because it goes far. IF YOU GET ANY ON YOUR FINGER AND TRY TO GET IT OFF YOU'LL PULL OFF THE WHOLE NAIL OF POLISH. IT'S ALL MEANT TO WORK TOGETHER and it does. I Ithought at the end it would be tacky not wet sticky and it is. Don't keep trying to dry it like I did. Just wipe it off with alcohol and you'll see it's beautifully shiny and dry. I've had it on almost two weeks and it's starting to peel on the edges slightly and I am not kind to my nails. Even though it's beginning to peel its still remarkably shiny. Ist the base coat, nail polish then Top coat sealer. It's completely worth it to spend the money for it. The cleaning stuff looks like alcohol in one bottle and acetone in the other. II wouldn't spend money on that again. II used the acetone and alcohol iI have here and it worked just as good. . II saved half the price going to the salon with the first use. My hubby was happy. Base coat must be sparring don't let it pool around the sides. What you put on the base and how it looks is how it will look with the rest of the coats. Happy manicures.

  75. Great UV light for curing gel nail polishes. There are a lot of reviews posted stating that the UV light does not dry their nail polish. You HAVE to apply isopropyl (alcohol) to a cotton ball and rub it over your nail AFTER you apply your top coat. This will rid any of that tacky feeling left on your nails and the gel polish will be dry.

  77. The only reason I give it 4 stars instead of 5 is because it doesn't come with instructions and recommended drying times for certain polishes. Also I only used regular nail polish, not gel. Like previous reviewer wrote: it is best to dry for complete 300 secs b4 after applying each coat. So 1st coat...then dry for 300 secs.... 2nd coat then dry for 300 secs.....3rd coat or final shine - then dry for 300 secs. I am also an amateur at doing my nails but I must say my nails are 100% passable as being professionally applied if you don't stare too hard.

  101. I really really love this dryer. I got my nails done for a year prior to ordering this, but due to how spendy it is I decided to go DIY, and I'm so glad I did. I do gel polish, so I don't do anything too crazy. I wanted a product that wasn't too expensive but that does a good job (as with all products), and this one does an excellent job. Love it. It's super easy to use. First I add the base coat, and then I cure it for 90 seconds, then I do the color. How many coats of polish I do depends on the color, but I cure it for 160 secs (two mins) with the color. Than I add the top coat and cure it for 160 secs as well, and viola! Perfect nails every time. My polish really lasts for 2+ weeks, holds up realllllyyy really well. I can use any brand of polish with this machine and it all lasts the same (I've use Gelish, IBD, and another brand I found on sale at Sally's). I would recommend this to anyone! It's an excellent price for how well it works.

I used this light with CND products and have successfully been doing my own shellac manicures! You do want to be aware of the minimum wattage necessary for each product and this is definitely the biggest and highest wattage for this price.   237. I've been curious about gel manicures for quite a few months now; really, ever since I first started seeing those Sally Hansen ads for the complete kit on TV. But after looking at the actual products in-store, and seeing that I'd have to shell out seventy bucks for a few tiny bottles of polish and an itty-bitty lamp, I had to stop and think about it. I waited a few months, then mentioned to my best friend that I wished I could get my nail polish to last more than just twelve hours before it started chipping off. That's when she told me that her sister - a chemistry teacher - had decided to try doing gel manicures, and had raved about how beautiful her nails looked weeks after doing them herself, even with having her hands in chemicals all day!<br /><br />I knew then that it was time to come to Amazon and start looking for the perfect products to outfit my set with, that I was going to treat myself to something super-girly for my 40th birthday, and gel manicure components were gonna be IT! The top-rated UV lamp that came up was this Royal Nails dryer, and it turns out that the popularity and high ratings are for GOOD reason! This thing is AWESOME!!!<br /><br />When I got my box, I was amazed at how big this lamp is! It really does, VERY comfortably, accommodate both hands or both feet for simultaneous curing, which is vital to keep from spending an hour trying to get your gel nails done, start to finish. Putting the bulbs in was also not at all difficult, once i'd unpacked the lamp, turned it over, unsnapped the two hooks that keep the bottom closed, and flipped the bottom open (be sure to remove the blue plastic mirror protection film - it's vital to ensuring a full, hard cure of the gel polish)! Once that was done, I was ready to go! The control panel of the lamp is at the back, behind the starburst fan vent, and it's easy enough to figure out on your own how to control it (even though the unit does come with an information pamphlet). There's no 60 second setting - it just goes directly to 90 seconds (1 1/2 minutes), then up from there. Curing my nails for 90, as opposed to 60, seconds has been great for curing them as needed for the foundation coat, and pretty much every other layer needs two minutes, which is the 120 second setting, so the lamp covers all the bases beautifully.<br /><br />With the UV lamp on for 120 seconds, by the end of it, my fingers are just starting to feel warmed, as if I've just laid in the sun, and there's absolutely no discomfort. To ensure that I don't have to worry about too much exposure, I bought myself a pair of [[ASIN:B006L6WNVG ROYAL NAILS ANTI UV GLOVES FOR UV LIGHT/LAMP NAIL DRYER ONLY NAIL EXPOSED]], which fit my hands snugly, keeping the fabric out of the way as I apply my polishes while wearing them. The polishes that I bought to round out my manicure set are [[ASIN:B006FRS9O6 Harmony Gelish Top and Base \\"Set of 2\\" Good Deal!!!]], which have been great, and were the full half ounce size, as opposed to the tiny mini bottles that Sally Beauty Supply stocks, for a higher price than I paid here, even! To go with the base and top coats, I got a bottle each of [[ASIN:B003VMF5S6 Harmony Gelish Uv Soak Off Gel Polish -Bronzed (0.5 Oz)]] - a beautiful, neutral glittery sand color, and [[ASIN:B003VMFITM Harmony Gelish UV Soak Off Gel Polish Good Gossip]], a beautiful, sparkly candy apple or ruby slipper red.<br /><br />I followed all of the steps recommended, both by Harmony Gelish, and various websites, blogs, and in multiple YouTube videos, to successfully do my gel manicures. If you've already done a manicure, the next few steps would be for soaking off the old polish:<br /><br />* A tip that I read recommended filing the surface of the existing gel manicure's polish to make it easier for the Acetone-based polish remover to get through the layers of polish. I then soaked the lint-free pads I'd pre-cut into quarters in standard nail polish remover with Acetone, placed them over my nails, and wrapped them with strips of aluminum foil that I'd pre-cut, and waited about 20 minutes for the remover to soak through the polish (your fingers will start to feel chilled once you've wrapped your fingers in the foil. It's a sign that the aluminum has activated the acetone in your polish remover, and is working as it should).<br /><br />* Once that was done, and the polish was softened and peeling away, I used an orange stick to push off the rest of the polish, then continued prepping my nails, washing my hands thoroughly to begin my new manicure. Once my hands and nails were washed, I used an orange stick to push EVERY bit of cuticle back, and a sharp implement (pocket knife, cuticle trimmer, etc) to carefully trim any cuticle (if you leave cuticle adhered to the nail, it'll cause your gel manicure to lift off). I then used a nail buffer - medium/fine side - to buff any sheen from my ENTIRE nail surface (skip this step and the foundation layer of gel polish may not adhere to your nail, and your polishes may lift). Once each nail was fully, but lightly, buffed, then filed to the shape/length I wanted, I soaked a lint-free pad in regular Isopropyl/rubbing alcohol (91% at least is recommended for gel nails), and wiped the surface of each nail clean. Once that's done, it's on to polish application!<br /><br />* Everything I've read online stresses NOT to touch the polish to your skin! Not so much for safety/health reasons, as that, once the polish adheres to your skin, it WILL cause your manicure to lift! Use an alcohol-soaked Q-tip to wipe away any polish that touches your skin before curing, and remember that, until you cure the polish under the UV/LED light, it's still effectively wet and movable. The first manicure I did, I applied each layer of polish too thickly - like I would've using regular nail polish (which this is NOT!), so the excess polish pooled around my nails' edges, and my manicure started to lift on about the 7th day on a few of my nails. My second time around, I made sure to gently scrub the foundation layer onto my nail using the brush's short bristles, but with a THIN layer, making sure I got all corners of my nail, but pushing out the bulk of the polish to my nail's edges so that each was coated in a thin layer, to the very edge of my nail. After curing, each subsequent layer (which will require a curing PER layer), was applied with an even, thin coat of polish, and each layer was \\"capped\\" by wiping a light layer of the polish used for that layer over my nail tips, to seal the color and polish in - this helps to avoid chips. I did four layers of polish overall - foundation (which I wiped with a DRY, lint free wipe or paper towel, just for a dry clean, as the Harmony Gelish instructions suggest), two coats of color - each cured individually, four fingers first for two minutes per coat, then the thumbs by themselves (to prevent the color from running to the side, as happened the first time I did a gel manicure!), two minutes again per layer. Once that was done, I applied a thin layer of topcoat (just don't make it TOO thin!), then cured that for two minutes on my fingers, then cured just my thumbs for the final two minutes.<br /><br />You'll be AMAZED once you've taken your nails out of the lamp after the topcoat layer, and wiped the sticky coating off using a lint free pad or paper towel! The shine and hardness is AMAZING! I'm still shocked by how fully dry and hard my nails are each time I do a gel manicure, and I LOVE looking down at my nails TWO WEEKS LATER to see that my polish job is STILL just as sparkly, wet-shine glossy, and gorgeous as the day I first did them!<br /><br />I did acrylic nails years ago, only for a year, and once I stopped, my nails were TRASHED! So far, my nails are growing out longer with each week, and they look healthy and gorgeous when I soak off my color. With the color on, they're feminine and beautiful! I couldn't be happier, and I have no doubt that THIS lamp is the way to go!Others may be a few bucks less, but they're all smaller, and not strong enough to fully cure your nails for a weeks-long manicure! This lamp looks like one you'd find in a professional salon, if not better, and works just as well, if not better, than the others out there! This thing is worth EVERY PENNY!!! LOVE IT!!!<br /><br />P.S. If you're willing to take a risk, check out ebay for cheap gel polishes from China. The wide selection of colors there is pretty mindblowing, so I've ordered a whole slew of polishes, but I have yet to receive mine, so I'm not sure how they'll compare to the \\"good\\" stuff like Harmony Gelish or Ulta's Red Carpet Manicure (which I used to add an extra layer of iridescent glitter over my Good Gossip Gelish polish during my last manicure - it worked just fine with Gelish)! The polishes I got on that other auction site all shipped free, and with 0.5 oz bottles that are about half to a third of the price of what I've gotten here and looked at at my local beauty supply store, for nearly double the product available in local stores, I figure it's worth the risk. I believe all of these polishes are made in China anyway, so I'm willing to risk it to see if they ARE effectively the same! I'll update here if I find my Chinese knock-offs are abysmal! Keeping my fingers crossed, though! ;)<br /><br />*UPDATE*<br /><br />I've received, and used, my first two (compatible)colors of less-expensive made in China gel polish, and so far, it's gone on and cured just fine. I LOVE Harmony Gelish polishes, as they have a gorgeous luster and sheen, and now that I've taken the time to look to see that they're made in America, that's a little more incentive for me to look for more colors when I really want to splurge (but I'll only buy them on Amazon, IF they're the half ounce size). My only real problem is getting gel polishes in a wider variety of colors, which is why I decided to try the made in China colors I found on ebay. So far, the sky blue and corresponding clear chunky glitter gel polish that I've received, have cured just as well as my Harmony Gelish colors did, and they're doing great sandwiched between my Harmony Gelish foundation and Top It Off top coat. I'm very tempted to say that the Harmony Gelish colors seem to have more luster and a more intense, glassy sheen to them, but I'm also being hyper critical of these miC (made in China) soak-off colors.<br /><br />*FURTHER UPDATE: Chinese gel removal issues!*<br /><br />The Chinese gels look pretty decent going on, but the one pair that I used with each other (again, sandwiched between my Harmony Gelish foundation and top coat) hadn't soaked off after 45 MINUTES - DOUBLE the time it takes my American-made Harmony Gelish, my new favorite, IBD Just Gel, or my Red Carpet Manicure glitters - I ended up having to SCRAPE them off with my sharp metal MiC cuticle pusher. So, I rescind my previous declaration - I DON'T think the made-in-China gels are worth the risk (all other Chinese products have been fine, though, except for the pink-and-clear fingertip nail soakers)! Besides, with the Customs restrictions that were put in place at the end of September 2013, it's taken an average of about EIGHT WEEKS for me to get those polishes! Other products arrive closer to the claimed time frame, but the polishes don't, and they smell MUCH stronger than the higher-priced, quality brands, along with looking inconsistent in the polish texture. I've had polishes arrive looking partially dried up and gloppy, with blobs of polish in the bottle, and the average MiC polish I've received is much thicker overall in texture, with far less of the luster and sheen of my Gelish, IBD, and RCM gels. I've now seen, eight bottles over, that the MiC gels I bought on eBay are another case of \\"you get what you pay for\\". They're cheap for a reason! NOT worth the money, and the damage to my nails to SCRAPE them off!e around, I made sure to gently scrub the foundation layer onto my nail using the brush's short bristles, but with a THIN layer, making sure I got all corners of my nail, but pushing out the bulk of the polish to my nail's edges so that each was coated in a thin layer, to the very edge of my nail. After curing, each subsequent layer (which will require a curing PER layer), was applied with an even, thin coat of polish, and each layer was \\"capped\\" by wiping a light layer of the polish used for that layer over my nail tips, to seal the color and polish in - this helps to avoid chips. I did four layers of polish overall - foundation (which I wiped with a DRY, lint free wipe or paper towel, just for a dry clean, as the Harmony Gelish instructions suggest), two coats of color - each cured individually, four fingers first for two minutes per coat, then the thumbs by themselves (to prevent the color from running to the side, as happened the first time I did a gel manicure!), two minutes again per layer. Once that was done, I applied a thin layer of topcoat (just don't make it TOO thin!), then cured that for two minutes on my fingers, then cured just my thumbs for the final two minutes.<br /><br />You'll be AMAZED once you've taken your nails out of the lamp after the topcoat layer, and wiped the sticky coating off using a lint free pad or paper towel! The shine and hardness is AMAZING! I'm still shocked by how fully dry and hard my nails are each time I do a gel manicure, and I LOVE looking down at my nails TWO WEEKS LATER to see that my polish job is STILL just as sparkly, wet-shine glossy, and gorgeous as the day I first did them!<br /><br />I did acrylic nails years ago, only for a year, and once I stopped, my nails were TRASHED! So far, my nails are growing out longer with each week, and they look healthy and gorgeous when I soak off my color. With the color on, they're feminine and beautiful! I couldn't be happier, and I have no doubt that THIS lamp is the way to go!Others may be a few bucks less, but they're all smaller, and not strong enough to fully cure your nails for a weeks-long manicure! This lamp looks like one you'd find in a professional salon, if not better, and works just as well, if not better, than the others out there! This thing is worth EVERY PENNY!!! LOVE IT!!!<br /><br />P.S. If you're willing to take a risk, check out ebay for cheap gel polishes from China.   243. Very happy with the unit. Nicer than what they use in the shops here. Works great. Easy to operation, very roomy.

  267. Ok... So this might be the most exciting review I have written in a while! I just received this nail lamp today after doing 2-day shipping because my salon gel nails needed a redo. I have been hesitant about buying a nail lamp because I was a bit skeptical, but I am soooo glad I finally decided to purchase this lamp after seeing all of the positive reviews! Just to be completely clear, I usually gel the Gelish polish done at the salon, so I did get the Gelish starter kit to have everything I needed for this at home experiment. I went through the process of removing my current gel and started fresh with the Gelish kit and the nail lamp. This lamp worked amazingly!! I set the timer for 180 minutes after each step and my gel manicure came out perfect on the first try!! I definitely recommend this lamp especially at this price for anyone who wants to do this at home! A note for everyone trying this at home: your nails will remain sticky after each 2 minute curing session until you put the top coat on and then wipe it off with the nail cleanser or nail polish remover after you are completely finished. If you follow the Gelish instructions you will be fine! I know this sounds like a lot but it was really easy!

  297. I purchased this dryer for my mom's birthday present. She was tired of paying to go to the salon so we decided to buy a dryer and do it ourselves. This dryer is larger that what I see in salons. You can dry both hands/feet at once. There are several different time settings and a fan. We did 3 peoples nails last night so the product has already paid for itself. We were all very pleased and will be using it a lot.
  298. I had my nails under the light for over 10 minutes and they never dried. Returning this and spending a little more on an OPI light.
  299. I love this nail dryer(model RN451), after shopping Amazon at great length I chose this model for it's wattage. It is 54 watts vs. many in the 36 watt range because it has 2 more bulbs to provice quicker drying times. It is much like many I have seen in professional salons, large enough for both hands or feet. While I only do I hand at a time doing gelish manicures on myself, I like the fact it was large enough with more than enough room for my hand. The unit is turned on with a power switch on the rear, then when drying time is needed, timers are set from five presets on the top for the need curing time. It also has a fan which I think would be great for regular polishes. After my 1st gelish home manicure, I am glad I took the plunge and bought this dryer and basix gelish kit. They will more than pay for themselves as I can do my nails at home and save time and money!
  300. Love it! Both hands fit in with plenty of room! This makes the job so much faster for me now!
  301. Changed my gel nails for the best. I was using the KISS LED lamp for the wash off gel nails and every week I had to remove and reapply the gel french manicure, because the polish would chip off the nails big time. So I tried another type of gel product with the KISS lamp and got the same chipping. Due to other reviewers, I decided to use the UV light and saw a big difference in the manicure and no chipping. I am very hard on my nails, I wash my hands a lot and wash dishes. So when my nails go through this much water and chemicals and stay on for more than a week, I am excited. Also, unlike the KISS LED light, I can place both hands in at one time, which reduces the manicure time. I would like to rate this five stars, but gave it a four star rating because the box did not have any instruction book on how to change or install the bulbs and how to order replacement bulbs. I watched a YouTube video to the get the directions.
  302. I am extremely satisfied with this product! I had my first shellac manicure at a salon & was so impressed with the results but I cannot afford over $50.00 every two weeks. Being a \\"do it yourself\\" person, I decided to make the investment in this UV light & have had great results with it. The quality matches any professional salon & it is easy to use. I would highly recommend it to anyone else that feels that they can \\"do it themselves\\"!!
  303. Hey Ladies,<br /><br />It's Dee in NY and this lamp gets 5 stars! It is very easy to assemble and even easier to use.<br /><br />I had a free trial of Amazon Prime, so the shipment arrived in two-days flat.<br /><br />The bulbs came individually bubble wrapped and boxed inside the larger boxes. There's not much information enclosed but all you do is release the bottom of the unit (don't force it; push in the \\"tabs\\") to insert the lightbulbs and peel off the blue protective coating on the mirror. Start by prepping nails to remove oils. Nails are cured in 2 minutes each for base, color and top coats. Wipe nails with plain alcohol (IPA) to remove stickiness and you're done. I only did one hand at a time but you can definitely fit two if you prefer.

As far as removing the nail gel, I think using a small glass custard bowl will work better than wrapping cotton/foil.

  339. it's about the same time as sitting at the salon. To start out, for each application I use the longest timer x2for each app. . This is my process; first, the base, then the color, then the color again and then the base coat. But after the base coat drying is finished, I take a small artists paint brush (like a toddlers size) and dip it in nail polish remover and then apply it to all the nails and then go back in the machine for a 2x cycle again. We have found if we don't do that, the top coat remains sticky. And, if you notice, they do that at the salon too.<br />it's 25.00 for toes for gel nail at our strip mall salon, so 2 times, its paid for !

PLEASE make sure you remove the fine film that is on all of the reflective surfaces inside that look like mirrors(Do this while you are putting in your bulbs).<br /><br />I Googled \\"Gel Nail Polish\\" and actually bought it from Amazon as well ([[ASIN:B004SSRSRS B004SSRSRS]]<br /><br />Now, PLEASE NOTE that you HAVE TO HAVE a base coat applied before applying your new Gel Nail Polish, and THEN you need a Top Coat. I purchased a Base Coat/Top Coat kit for her here on Amazon too ([[ASIN:B005MG86TY B005MG86TY]]<br /><br />REMEMBER: After you cure the Top Coat it WILL BE TACKY!!!! You MUST remove the top coat with a non lint cloth and some isopropyl alcohol (You simply swipe the alcohol pad/cloth over the nail, removing the top thin coat). Sounds weird, why would you have to take it off after you just put in on? Well, it helps cure your nail coating and looks shiney and beautiful after removing it! Again, plenty of YouTube videos showing you how to do this!<br /><br />Remember Google is your friend, and so is YouTube. There are a ton of videos on how to do all of this yourself, if you don't already know what you are doing of course. I'm one of those guys that likes to research everything I purchase and learn how everything works.<br /><br />My wife's nails look absolutely AMAZING. They look like she just walked out of a professional nail salon. This UV Dryer/Curer dries them evenly and FAST (1-3 minutes per coat).<br /><br />My wife is HAPPY, which makes ME happy, and we save a lot of $$$.   349. Perfect for at home gel nails
  350. This is a great UV nail dryerI received this light for Christmas, it arrived very quickly and in an undamaged box just like the one shown in the picture. It included 6 bulbs packaged in cardboard inside of the dryer. I plugged in the lamps and powered it on with no problems. There are three buttons, a power button to turn on the lamps, a timer button to select how long you want the lamps to stay on, and a fan button to turn the small fan on and off. The dryer is large, about the size of a show box and on the heavier side, but has plenty of room to cure both hands or both feet at the same time. So far I've used the lamp with OPI GelColor as well as China Glaze Gelaze polish. All colors both glitters and cream polishes have cured with no problems.<br />A few tips I have from assembly and use:<br />When inserting the lamps, press inward on the two tabs on the bottom and the whole top will lift up on a hinge in the back.<br />Make sure you remove the blue plastic covering from all surfaces and then press the top back down firm and carefully until it clicks into place.<br />I use the typical 1,2,3 method wit gels. 1 minute to cure the base, 2 minutes for each layer of color, and then 3 minutes for top coat.<br /><br />I've read through some negative reviews stating it did not sure their polish. A UV bulb will cure all UV gel polish if it is applied correctly. There is something called a dispersion layer that will rise to the surface of each gel layer. This is a sticky film on the nail surface and should be wiped off with alcohol at the end of the manicure. No matter how long you cure your nails that layer will not go away until you clean it off. This does not mean that the light it defective, you have just failed to do your research.<br /><br />Overall I recommend this nail lamp/dryer for personal use with UV gels and even regular nail polish to shorten dry time. I give it 4 stars for price power and functionality, if it were a bit more compact and lightweight it would be perfect.<br />Enjoy!e perfect.<br />Enjoy!

  360. I decided to purchase this light along with the OPI gel base coat, nail polishes and top coat so I could do my own manicures at home. I've owned the system for about 2 months and have done my nails and friends' nails about 10 times so far. Love the light - nice to have the width to cure both hands at once. The fan is also good for pulling in fumes. You have the option to cure in 30 second increments, up to about 4 minutes. I typically cure each coat about 90-120 seconds and the final coat 180 seconds. I love being able to change polishes for color or to avoid the grow-out look. It costs about $80 to buy the light, base & top coat and two polishes - basically the same as 2 manicures so I've definitely saved money.<br /><br />It takes less than 30 minutes for me to paint nails. With removal, trimming and shaping, it's about an hour long process. Make sure you read up on the polish you use - for example, make sure you wipe over your nails with alcohol after the top coat cures. This final step is what hardens and shines the polish completely. I use the foil method for removal - works great for me. Some of my friends find they can peel off the polish easily once it starts lifting in a corner. I'm not really able to do so. I guess there's a difference in nail texture for some people.

Also, be careful when you put your feet in the dryer - make sure your feet are on the floor and slide them in without lifting them up. I bumped one of my toes against the top portion of the opening and had to reapply that polish.<br /><br />I can't count the number of times that I've applied regular polish to my nails and ruined them hours later because the polish was not fully set. The Royal Nails dryer has eliminated that problem. Even if you don't buy this to cure the UV polishes, it works great for regular polish.<br /><br />The product photos do not show the location for the operating controls. The timer and fan controls are just behind the starburst on the top of the dryer. The on/off switch is on the back side of the dryer. Also, the outside measurements of the dryer are 14\\" wide x 10\\" deep x 7\\" high. The lid is hinged and opens wide for the bulb installation. The timer settings (in seconds) are: 90, 120, 180, 240 and 300.<br /><br />I shopped around for days trying to make my mind up about which dryer to buy.   486. I had a formal event that I had to attend unexpectedly, and my nails were NOT in good shape for it. I went to a nail salon that my friend recommended and got a set of gel nails. The nails looked great, and I was thrilled with the way mine were able to finally grow out with the extra strength the gel adds, but knew I would not keep them up at a cost of $40 every couple weeks.<br /><br />I googled the name of the polish the salon used (Gelish), and saw the products were available online. I then started reading reviews for the UV lights, and this one had great reviews. I decided to pull the trigger and buy the lamp and gels and try them myself at home. I am NOT a nail tech, have absolutely no formal training, but am pretty handy at figuring things out. The lamp arrived, I watched a couple of youtube videos of how to apply the gels, and jumped in. I AM THRILLED WITH MY RESULTS!!!!!! This UV light is awesome!!!! It is big enough to fit both hands in at once, has several \\"timer\\" options for how long you want the light to run, and also has a fan you can turn on at the same time. It looks great, seems solidly made, and I kid you not, my nails looked just as good as when I left the salon my first time! I was so excited with how they looked that I had to go show my husband and teenage sons as well : )<br /><br />A few things I'd point out, they might be obvious to a professional, but for the other newbies like me, here they are:<br /><br />-The bottom of the dryer swings open for ease in inserting the bulbs and removing the blue film. I didn't realize this until after I inserted the first few bulbs, MUCH easier with it opened up!<br />-The instructions said to remove the blue film covering the mirror sides on the inside of the dryer. I emailed the seller (Blue Novelties)to see if this also meant the \\"floor\\" and \\"roof\\" of the dryer or just the sides, they responded right away and said to also remove it from the top and bottom mirrors.<br />-When using the foundation gel, I cured for 1 minute, that was enough<br />-When using the lighter color (\\"Glamour Queen\\"), I cured for 2 minutes; when I applied the darker shades (\\"Samuri\\", \\"Black Cherry Berry\\") I cured for 3 minutes.<br />-When I applied the shiny clear top coat, I cured 2 minutes.<br />-I used rubbing alcohol and a scrap of cotton fabric to remove the tackiness at the end, no need to purchase special lint free cloths or special tackiness remover. If you skip this step, your nails will not feel like they are cured, but they are!<br />-To remove the nails, I just used 100% acetone (drugstore brand), put it on a cut up cotton ball and held to my finger with Grafco finger cots I ordered from Amazon. This worked great, I didn't want to soak my fingers in the acetone as it seems it would dry the skin out that way.<br />-I did not use any special nail oils, just put lotion on my hands when I was done.<br />-At about 10-12 days the nails start to show the unpolished area where they are growing out. I just put a coat of regular nail polish close in color to the gel over the entire nail, and get an extra 5-7 days wear before I have to redo them. I'm redoing the nails about every 3 weeks this way.<br /><br />I've now done 3 sets of the nails over the course of 9 weeks, and I am THRILLED that I bought this! No more trying to get an appointment that works with my schedule, and I've already saved enough to cover the purchase price. I can take the nails off one night while watching TV, and do a new set right away or the next night while watching another show. The lamp is quiet, looks great and works as promised. It may not be the cheapest lamp out there, but I truly believe you get what you pay for, and this light is worth every penny. It gives salon quality results for a fraction of the price, and it saves you a ton of time, because you can cure both hands at once between coats.<br /><br />I'd highly recommend this UV Light, and definitely this seller. I always appreciate a quick reply to my questions if I'm not sure about how to use a product , and they replied right away. I'll try to post pictures of how my nails looked after doing this - I FINALLY have nails that grow out, and without the big \\"ridge\\" that the old-style acrylic nails left when growing out!uick reply to my questions if I'm not sure about how to use a product , and they replied right away.   514. I was confused reading completely different 5star & 1star reviews... anyway, i bought it. I tried & came to conclusion that 1stars are correct: it doesn't dry the nails!!! but I researched & found out that me & all those who didn't write good reviews just don't know how to use it...<br />I'm putting 4 stars only because this lamp doesn't have instructions with it, which would make it perfect & everyone would be happy! because it has no instructions, many people use it in a wrong way & write bad reviews or return the product.<br />I will just give some instructions but u can search the web & youtube & find the right way to do shellac!!!<br />1. have clean nails.<br />2. put the base coat & put your fingers into the lamp with the regime 120-180 seconds.<br />IMPORTANT!!! don't touch your nails to make sure they are dry cause they are not & it's NORMAL!!! just CONTINUE with some patience!!!<br />3. put the color and again dry with UV lamp.<br />4. put another layer of color to have better results with rich color and dry again.<br />5. put the top coat & dry again.<br />and only now,<br />6. put some alcohol on a cotton and wipe your fingers to remove the sticky thing.<br />& only now<br />7. touch your fingers & enjoy them!!!

  540. I bought this UV light because I was tired of paying a salon to do it for me. All in all, I'm pretty satisfied with this light. I just wanted to point out a couple things about this light for those considering buying it.<br /><br />1. This is a UV light. Some gel polishes are made fo UV light, and some are made for LED. That said, UV lights are supposed to be able to cure most types of gel polishes regardless. I've tried OPI, Gelish, China Glaze, and Sensationail's gel polishes with the Royal Nails UV light and found that it will cure them all.<br /><br />2. Be aware of the size. This is a double sized light so that both of your hands, or both of your feet can dry at once. It's much bigger than the single sized one that you might be familiar with from the salon. This isn't a big deal to be but if you want to take it with you anywhere it's a bit clunky.<br /><br />3. Although UV lights are supposed to cure in about 2 minutes I have found that this light takes a little longer than that. I typically have to leave it in for about 4 minutes for it to cure properly. I'm not sure why but if I only leave it in for 2 minutes my nails tend to be left feeing a little tacky.
  541. Absolutely in love with this product I would definitely recommend this item for anyone who is interested . In having an excellent product at a great price!! Don't hesitate to buy it worth every penny!
  542. I bought this for my grown daughter and she is very pleased with it. She can dry the polish on both hands at the same time in about 15 minutes. I'm going to get one for my granddaughter for her birthday.
  543. Works very well with the gelish brand top foundation and nail polish. Yoh can do both hands at a time, it's big enough for 2 hands
  544. I like the dryer, but after doing manicure a couple of times, I wish I went with a smaller one hand nail UV polish dryer like I see in the salons (Essie and OPI). They both have touch sensors inside so when you put your hand back in, timer goes on and you can see the seconds count down on the display on top. Drying 2 hands at the same time is not a good idea, since gel polish doesn't set until you dry it for 60-90 seconds under the lamp so you simply cannot apply gel polish if your other hand nails are wet. Also when you turn your hand, polish tends to run to the side of hand which is pointing down. I discovered that it is best to put your hand flat the entire time until gel or shellac is completely dry, which is best done one hand at a time. I this dryer is a good product when you have a friend doing your manicure.

I also bought a UV gel base and top coat pair by Gelish for about ~$21. You don't need to spend money on Gel nail polish, just use your own between both Gel base and top coats. Make sure all layers are fully dry otherwise the top coat will shrivel the underlying nail coats if they're not fully dry - ugly results! So, Use very minimal applications of paint/gel.

  632. I used to go to the nail salon to get gel polish for my nails every two weeks and it costs $40 (plus the tip). This Dryer is great! I've done my nails several times and they look just as good as if I went to the salon! I don't know if the machine has anything to do with this but I've found that Gelish polish products don't work with well with Opi base and top coat. But using Opi products together give you a wonderful outcome. My nails cure quickly but you have to cure at least 90 seconds for EACH step. And like another buyer's statement that your nails will feel wet between steps is correct so don't touch them until you've cured the top coat. Then just wipe with alcohol and your nails will be dry, shiny and beautiful. A great buy for the money and fun to do because you can afford to change your polish more often.<br /><br />It's been a few weeks after getting my machine. I really wanted to come back and add my experience with Blue Novelities. One of my bulbs blew so I sent them an email out to ask about how I could get replacement bulbs. Light worked great for shellac. Used fan for toes. It's a nice quiet gentle fan that does not give those nasty bubbles you get when doing your nails and the house air or a ceiling fan is blowing. My nails look better than when I had them done in salon. I am sure it is a combo of this excellent light and the freshness if the CND Shellac I just got off amazon as well. It was totally the product in the salon being either old or too thick....also those bottles are opened over and over for use on various people. They will get older faster than mine will.   749. This is an absolutely fantastic product, and has worked even better than I expected. I use it with CND shellacs, and my home manicures have lasted around 2.5 weeks even though I work with my hands a lot. I gave up on regular nail polish a long time ago because I'd only get one or two days without bad chips, even with salon manicures. I also love having this light at home because if I do get a chip in the shellac, I can just re-do one nail (I uses the UV protection gloves pulled up over my other nails while in the light), and still get another week or more without having to re-do the entire manicure. I follow the CND shellac application instructions exactly, except I will sometimes cure the second coat of a very dark color for a bit longer than two minutes (I noticed this is what the salon did). I've also learned to trust the second color coat- the first coat needs to be thin, and may look a bit streaky, but with the CND shellacs, once you add the second coat, it all smooths out and looks perfect. With a little bit of practice, my manicures now turn out better than what I've got at salons, and for an initial investment of about two salon manicures, I can have long-lasting nail color anytime I want. I also love that the nails are rock-hard as soon as they come out of the light- I used to try so hard to let my nails dry, and then I'd accidentally hit something hard with my hand and end up with a bump or scrape in the polish.

It works well when it works, but the timer stops responding after 3 minutes of use and the whole unit overheats quickly. When this happens, nothing works and there is no way to turn it off but to unplug it from the power source. After hours of trial, I realize that the key is to keep the unit from overheating. A fan is integrated into the unit and it does keep the unit cooler when you turn it on, but does eliminate the malfunction. You just have to allot extra time to wait between hands (if you are using it on your own) to allow the unit to cool down. I wouldn't recommend this particular brand.

  771. I like this lamp for many reasons, but the main reason is because it gets the job done. This is the most professional UV lamp that I have had, it is not of cheap quality, and it shipped really quickly.. I used it 3 times so it's already paid for itself.. My mom loves it so much that she actually wants her own... If you're looking to purchase this for personal or professional use you will not be disappointed with the execution, however I'm not to happy with the timers, they're not working... But it does have a working fan...<br /><br />For the record most professional nail salons who advertise Gel manicures haven't mastered the art of doing the job properly, however I managed to find a salon that has and I pretty much follow their routine...<br /><br />After filing shaping and cleaning the cuticles...<br />1. Buff Nails (lightly).<br />2. Wash hands thoroughly.<br />3. Apply a thin layer of a Gel Prep Coat (Cuccio brand preferably).<br />4. Cure nails for 1 min (Royal 54 watt UV).<br />5. Apply a thin layer of a Gel Base coat (Cuccio brand pref).<br />6. Cure nails for 5 min.<br />7. Apply a thin layer of the first Gel color coat (Cuccio brand pref).<br />8. Cure nails for 5 min<br />9. Apply a thin layer of the second Gel color coat<br />10. Cure nails for 5 min.<br />11. Apply a thin layer of a Gel Top coat (Cuccio pref).<br />12. Cure nails for 5 to 10 minutes.<br />13. Saturate a cotton ball with rubbing alcohol and use it to clean the film off each nail.

  831. This light is super easy to use and works like it's supposed to work. AND pays for itself very quickly. The trick to having a great gel nail manicure, I believe, is getting the right shellac product - well, and this light. I tried a base coat and colors that my nail tech purchased for me and got a terrible end result. I am just coming off having acrylic nails (again - sheesh, I feel like I'll never learn) and my poor nails are now recovering. I've had several gel/shellac manicures over the last few eyars and love the way they hold up and how shiny the finish stays for the entire 2+ weeks but I don't have a reliable place to get them done in my town PLUS I don't really want to pay $35+ every 2-3 weeks.<br /><br />One reviewer gave a great suggestion that I've just tried - putting on the base coat, drying for 90 seconds, then putting on the top coat and drying for 3-4 minutes, using alcohol to remove the tacky layer and then polishing with whatever color you choose. I've so far just done the base and top coat (use CND) and will be putting a color on today for New Years Eve. I'll see how this works because this great reviewer said that when she wants to change the color, she just uses regular remover and the shellac base and top coat are left untouched. Then she files down the little ridge at the cuticle grow out, redoes the base and top coat and she doesn't have to remove w/the acetone. I love this idea and will try it.<br /><br />I also use this light for regular polish and it helps the polish set up nicely. I'm so glad I purchased (especially at the great price offered here on Amazon.com - a great value for the price) and the seller ships promptly w/good packaging. Follow the directions offered by other reviewers for a perfect shellac manicure - 90 seconds for base coat, 120 for first coat of color, 120 for 2nd coat of color, 180 or 240 seconds for top coat. Don't forget to spray w/alcohol and wipe off the tacky layer left after drying and you will be super thrilled with your nails. I'll repost after I try the technique I described above and let you know what I experience.per thrilled with your nails. I'll repost after I try the technique I described above and let you know what I experience.

The extra wide size and the high wattage were what attracted me to purchase this particular UV light. A good friend of mine works at a salon and recommended that I purchase a light with a 36 watt or higher wattage. For the money, this 54 watt light was the best deal out there!!! This friend was just over for dinner and when she saw the light she commented, \\"Wow, that's nicer than the one we use in our salon\\"!!!<br /><br />It is light and easily stored in my cabinet when not in use. Takes about 1 minute to cure gel and shellac polishes. I would HIGHLY recommend this light!!! Within a week, I have recouped my money by doing friend's nails. It's fun, easy and you will save yourself and all your friends an enormous amount of money in those salons!!!
  928. I requested this light for Christmas and used it the next day. Very easy to use. I used Sensationail polish primer and top coat with it. I know the verdict is still out on the safety of gel nails, but I'm gonna go for it . I stopped painting my nails a long time ago because I can't stand how fast regular polish chips. Getting this done in the salon every two weeks is not a good use of my money, so this is a viable option for now. It has the light with timer options and a regular fan option. I think people should be aware that even though this is LED, it is still UV. It all depends on what spectrum cures the polish you are using. I use the protective gloves (sold separately) and sunscreen when I use it.

  951. This light is clearly amazing for a UV light, holding at 5 stars with a whopping 500 plus reviews. I decided, before ordering it, to find replacement bulbs first, because I have read that UV lights require occasional replacement bulbs. I found the right bulbs, each nine watt, and to order six of them for this 54 watt lamp, my order for bulbs cost as much as the lamp itself. So I held my finger over the &#34;Place Order&#34; button, here on Amazon, completely convinced that this UV lamp is absolutely NOT A MISTAKE purchase. I always research before I buy, and I am still convinced this light is one of the best UV LAMPS AVAILABLE, better than the one my nail gal uses at the shop. But the cost to replace the bulbs stopped me from pressing to order. I ended up buying a lovely LED light instead, because I should never have to replace the bulbs and end up doubling or tripling or quadrupling the cost of the original light by buying bulbs. That said, I didn't want to drop $250 for an LED light, either. I found an LED light for $109, it is awesome, and I love that it cures my gels in 30 seconds a layer! BUT, and it is a big but, I was able to pay a little over 50 bucks more for the LED light, and many gals don't have that option. I worried that I had made a bad choice, and maybe my fabulous LED light will break on me. So far, I'm in love with the super fast cures. I am too much of a klutz to paint all my fingernails on both hands to cure all eight fingers at once to save on curing time. So LED ALLOWS ME TO DO QUICK BETWEEN-layer cures. And I love that. HOWEVER, if I had purchased a UV LIGHT, this was my choice, and I recommend it to friends AND RELATIVES who can't afford to drop over $50 more for my LED. REVIEWS TALK! All these customers who have this light swear by it, except for a dismal few who had bad experiences, for whatever reason. If you can't afford an LED, I truly feel this is the best buy out there. If I hadn't been able to step up to LED, I would have this light and probably love it. I really like that it has a fan, plus the light, to dry regular nail polish fast. I talked with a nail tech about &#34;gelly sandwiches&#34; which begin with gel bonder, the gel base coat, regular polish, and a gel top coat. This allows you to use your stash of regular polish for fun colors. I have so many colors that I love in regular polish! My LED may help dry them faster, but probably not. So though I will save on replacing bulbs with my fab LED light, maybe I will regret that my LED doesn't dry regular polish. And, hello, to replace all my regular polish with gel colors would be very costly. In short, did I make a smart choice? This light rocks according to reviews. I was more concerned about time spent doing my nails. 30 second cures between layers means a lot to this busy lady.<br /><br />By the way, in all these fab reviews, I've seen references to heaps of very expensive gel polishes. I use IBD GEL from base to top, and they are fabulous for so much less. Durable, great color selection, and I am in love. It is the brand my nail tech put on my nails, so I knew IBD WAS GREAT! I ordered Good Gossip from Gellish, at a bigger cost, because i found it online as as a true ruby slipper color, one of my favorites, only to discover that the Cosmic Red from IBD is the same &#34;ruby slipper&#34; color. Now I have two ruby slipper bottles. I will send one to my niece. First I will compare the durability of the two brands, but with my IBD COLORS WEARNG SO WELL, I will never pay the much higher price again. Hello? Why would anyone pay dollars more for another brand? I don't get it.<br /><br />No, I am not an IBD rep. I am a novelist who is busy and needs to do her nails at midnight, or whenever I find time. Appointments? For my hair and doctors, only. Going to the salon takes at least three hours to get my nails done, including driving time. I don't feel pampered; instead I feel stressed. At home, it is a treat, and IBD gels, or probably the more expensive gels as well, lend my fragile, chipping, peeling nails strength. With gels I have gorgeous nails, and this light would, I feel certain, give me just as good a cure, taking longer. Not here to sell anyone on anything. I think this light is a great buy, just research the cost of replacement bulbs before you hit &#34;Place Order.&#34; And find out how often UV bulbs must be replaced. I don't know. If they last for two years, how much will you save by doing your own gels? And, with this light, you can also do &#34;gelly sandwiches&#34; faster because of the fan and heat. Do your math for your wallet. I think this light is stellar, above and beyond most UV lights, and I nearly bought it.. Don't know yet if my LED will stand the test of time.. I think this light would.he more expensive gels as well, lend my fragile, chipping, peeling nails strength. With gels I have gorgeous nails, and this light would, I feel certain, give me just as good a cure, taking longer. Not here to sell anyone on anything. I think this light is a great buy, just research the cost of replacement bulbs before you hit &#34;Place Order.&#34; And find out how often UV bulbs must be replaced. I don't know. If they last for two years, how much will you save by doing your own gels? And, with this light, you can also do &#34;gelly sandwiches&#34; faster because of the fan and heat. Do your math for your wallet. I think this light is stellar, above and beyond most UV lights, and I nearly bought it.. Don't know yet if my LED will stand the test of time.. I think this light would.

There is no digital timer that counts down the seconds, and the fan stays on after the lights time out. These are minor things that take some getting used to after using the CND lamp. I cured my base coat after about 10-20 seconds (no timer so I just guessed) then cured the next coats at 120 seconds, then the top coat at about 160 seconds. I used all CND shellac and it worked perfectly.

But I was pleasantly surprised! I love that it's the &#34;real deal&#34; because it works wonderfully! I've already used it on myself and friends/family many times and it worked beautifully each and every time. It never failed! The only thing I regret is that I didn't do enough research prior to purchasing a UV lamp vs an LED lamp. There's been news circulating about the harmful effects of the UV rays emitted by these machines and is linked to skin cancer. It is advised to apply an SPF sunblock on your hands and skin around your nails prior to use or wearing gloves that have the tips cut off. I haven't done either of these things because I'm too lazy so I do wish I had purchased an LED lamp, not becuase they work better, but because I'm too lazy to take the advised precautions. However, LED lamps cost considerably more than UV and it's harder to find a decent one for purchase. But if you are looking for a good UV lamp, this one's it!

My box did not come with instructions so I was unaware I needed to do this until I read someone else's review.   1087. I had two problems...<br /><br />1- I read a review that mentioned how easy it was to install the lamps and pull out the blue film out of the dryer ONCE YOU OPENED THE TOP. The problem was, the instructions that came with the package had NO information on how to to that. (And I was afraid to force it and brake it) I contacted the seller and they answered me with the NEW instructions on an e-mail (during the holidays). It's true... It is MUCH easier to to all of these when you open the TOP. (In case yours come without those instructions too, I'll tell you at the end of this review)<br /><br />2- When I finished my nails I thought it didn't work. (I'm a beginner). I finished and sprayed them with 99% alcohol (Like the girl at the salon does) and washed them in the sink and they were still tacky. THEN when I was trying to remove the polish to start again, they were perfect. One thing NO ONE TELLS beginners like me is... They are Tacky at the end. You MUST rub them with the alcohol and wash them intensively in the sink with soap.<br />I have so far done 2 manicures and they turned out perfect! I followed some other review and I leave 120 seconds on base coat and each gel coat and put the max. 300 seconds at the end (Just to be sure). But It probably can be done with less time.<br /><br />HOW TO OPEN THE DRIER:<br /><br />Flip it upside down. There are two plastic wholes with some plastic hook in each. You have to slide the plastic hook out of the whole and lift The BOTTOM up. Mine came kind of crooked so I needed my husband's help for strength to open it.<br />Even with the force applied, it did not brake.<br /><br />THIS DRYER IS GREAT! And great priced too. GET IT.

  1101. Had a cheap, small, portable UV light which had served its time (not long, you get what you pay for). So when that one died, I decided to spend the money and get a real one. This is it! My days of professional expensive manis and pedis are over. I do a regular mani/pedi for myself anytime it suits me, for pennies. The big trick? A clear top coat called Seche Ultra-V which I buy at my neighborhood beauty supplies store. (Not sure if Amazon carries it.) Finish my mani and pedi with this clear top coat, then cure under the SUPER UV light, and voila, it's like instant gel nails without the high cost of gel polish and professional processing. The end result is similar to spray paint with a clear lacquer. No chipping, no scuffs, no scratches, no fading. So no need to invest in gel polishes. On the one hand, they are expensive, and on the other hand, the color choices are limited.<br /><br />Oh, and the best part of all? When you feel like a change of color? It comes off like regular polish. No need to soak off gel polish. My days of professional mani and pedi are done! Yabbadabbadoooooo!

My nails were still sticky when I finished the top coat, so I let them sit under the dryer for an extra 20 minutes. I never have to sit that long at the salon, and when I leave the salon my nails are perfectly dry. It also has the option to just leave the light on constantly. The built in fan keeps it from over heating which is also a nice feature. It has a sturdy design and easily cures my Gelish polish in no time. The only issue I had was initially getting it open to install the light bulbs, but that was more me not wanting to mess up my current manicure at the time. A little help from someone without a pretty manicure and it all was good.<br /><br />Now I'm able to do my nails at home for a fraction of the cost of going to the salon, and even for my friends! Sometimes they even let me try out different colors and designs on them. Why not? When you have the ability to change it yourself.

  1188. I'm very active as a swimmer/runner, but it's scrubbing dishes around the house with my fingernails that really does them in. I got into gel nails a few months ago to try and protect my nails from breaking and look professional when I go to work. So far, the gel system has worked really well and I love the durability. I bought this lamp when assembling my kit and here are a couple of things I wish I'd known about gels in general and this lamp in particular when I was getting started.<br /><br />1. This lamp is really big. It takes up an entire shelf in my bathroom linen closet. If you do your nails yourself as I do, you're only going to need to do one hand at a time anyway. A smaller system would probably have fit my lifestyle better.<br /><br />2. The lamp is sturdy, well constructed and the little fan is nice to move the air as it can get hot under the UV lights. The buttons are easy to push -- which matters when you have wet nails!<br /><br />3. Gel polish is viscous and moves when it's wet, so you aren't likely to do a whole hand and let it sit there before you put it under the light to set. Thus far, I've only managed to do a finger or 2 at a time before needing to cure it. Especially when building a nail with the base coat.<br /><br />4. That being said, Gel polish cures in 30 seconds with LED lights and in 2 minutes with UV light. That means, using a UV light like this one, it takes 2 minutes, minimum. Per finger. Per coat. Every. Time. So... a base coat, plus two coats of color, plus 1 top coat (doing two fingers at a time per application) is 24 minutes under the UV light PER HAND. And if you are building a nail with 2-3 base coat applications, add to that. Perhaps it is faster if doing someone else's nails -- where you can manage a whole hand at a time, or after I'm more experienced at it. But I wish I had known the difference in curing times between LED and UV systems and had had a better idea of the length of time it took to cure before purchasing my system. Keep in mind how much time you have to devote to your nail process before deciding whether to go with an LED or UV system.<br /><br />5. Gel nails take a long soak in acetone to get off. I did my toes when I first got the kit... and love the look. Which is good, because I haven't mustered up the courage to soak my feet in acetone long enough to get the polish off... Somehow getting the polish off my hands (by soaking cotton balls in acetone and wrapping the nails in tinfoil doesn't seem as hard as doing that to my toes. I love the fact that this kit is big enough for both my feet, but I'm thinking that i may stick to regular polish on my feet in the future and keep my gels for my hands where the durability is really needed. But to each her own!<br /><br />6. I gave this a 4 star rating because I truly like the lamp. It feels really durable, was super easy to assemble (put the lights in the lamp) and works! It may be more lamp than I really need, but it's giving me the nails I want. Super!em. Keep in mind how much time you have to devote to your nail process before deciding whether to go with an LED or UV system.<br /><br />5. Gel nails take a long soak in acetone to get off. I did my toes when I first got the kit... and love the look. Which is good, because I haven't mustered up the courage to soak my feet in acetone long enough to get the polish off... Somehow getting the polish off my hands (by soaking cotton balls in acetone and wrapping the nails in tinfoil doesn't seem as hard as doing that to my toes. I love the fact that this kit is big enough for both my feet, but I'm thinking that i may stick to regular polish on my feet in the future and keep my gels for my hands where the durability is really needed. But to each her own!<br /><br />6. I gave this a 4 star rating because I truly like the lamp. It feels really durable, was super easy to assemble (put the lights in the lamp) and works! It may be more lamp than I really need, but it's giving me the nails I want. Super!

I was still happy. But today is day 2 and nail paint fell off completely from the nail. So disappointed with this product.   1192. Amazing product! You get the same quality of gel nails as you would from a salon & the machine pays for itself very quickly. I haven't needed to cure anything longer than 90 seconds but there is a timer with multiple settings. I got the gelish starter kit and some opi gel polishes and it looks amazing! My friends want me to do theirs (and will pay) so everyone wins! Those who rate one star need to do their homework & look up how to apply gel polish and in what order (there's a lot of bottles, it can get confusing) but the last step is to wipe the nails with a cotton ball and rubbing alcohol to take the tackiness off the top! Nails are instantly dry after this. Seriously, you will not regret this product!

  1253. I was using one of those small handheld lamps before this, and it worked okay, but I wanted to be able to do both hands at once and with a stronger wattage. I was fortunate enough to buy this when it was a little less expensive than what it is listed for right now. I am completely happy with my purchase. All of the bulbs worked right out of the box. The only thing that I was a little weird about was the fan. I'm thinking the fan is purely to keep some air flow going and to maybe keep your hands cooler under the light (not that they get super hot or anything) because it surely doesn't blow enough air to aid in drying nail polish. Not a deal breaker for me though, so it's fine.<br /><br />I use this only for curing a gel top coat. I do not do a gel base coat or gel polish. I prefer to change my nail color every week and removing all of those gel layers would be a pain in my opinion, even though there are methods to make it easier (see YouTube). I also own over 150 bottles of regular nail polish that I do not want to replace with gel polishes. Yes, I am addicted to nail polish and even built my own rack to store them! My current favorite way to go is to use CND Stickey base coat, any polish (even really cheap ones and always two coats), and Red Carpet gel top coat. I believe the Red Carpet directions say two minutes under the lamp, but I do three. With a bit of pressure, rub each nail with a cotton pad soaked in alcohol after they are cured. Mine come out super shiny and last the whole week looking perfect. I don't know how long they last after that because I like to change things up and do a different color. To remove, I lightly file some of the top coat off and then wipe with acetone. It usually comes off pretty easily. I don't have the patience to soak off three or four layers of gel, which is why I do things this way.

  1309. This is my first time ever with a shellac manicure. This is by far amazing and so easy to use. The first time was trial and error, I did not realize the importance of a base coat and top coat. The first time I used it, I did not use the BC/TC and put CND Shellac Fedora on. It came out horrible, it shrunk and did not coat the nail evenly. So I quickly removed it, went to the store and purchased the CND BC and TC and voila, so nice. There are a few important things to keep in mind though. First and foremost is to shake shake shake the bottles up. I cannot stress this enough, I think that's why Fedora was so horrible on my first try (as well as the lack of basecoat). The next thing is, to cure the base coat for 10 seconds only. Trust me, that's all it takes. Then proceed as usual. The last important thing is to use 99% alcohol to remove the tackiness. Don't use anything less, I thought the 97% alcohol I had would be fine but no such luck. It dulled the manicure and made it look horrible. I purchased the 99% and it was like glass. Perfect. I can't wait to use this again. I highly recommend this item for your shellac/gel mani/Pedi's.

  1339. I work in a salon that does nails. We use the O.P.I. lamp which is very expensive. I bought this lamp for home/personnel use, and I have to say I think it works even better than the O.P.I. lamp! For the people that give it a negative review saying it didn't dry or cure your nails, your probably doing it wrong. Each gel polish manufacturer has different curing times so you may want to check that out. Also your nails will always have a sticky wet feel to them after you've successfully completed and cured a set of gel nails. You need to take NON acetone nail polish remover or a product like nas99<br />(I think o.p.I. sells it) and wipe them off one at a time with a decent amount of pressure until the tacit feeling is gone. I just use soap and water and a wash cloth and am able to get the same result. Using an acetone. Remover will make them look dull and starts to remove the gel polish. Lastely most gel polishes have a required base coat and top coat that you also need to cure. I hope this helps anyone having issues with their gel sets and I encourage everyone to buy this lamp. The only thing I cant say for it yet is the longevity of the lamp since ive only had it a few months.

  1341. This lamp works better than the Ikonna UV lamp because it has one extra bulb (54 watt vs Ikonna's 45 watt).<br /><br />The price? Well the Royal costs 1/3 less than the Ikonna.<br /><br />The Royal UV lamp is easier to handle because it is lighter. The light weight helps tremendously if you don't have a UV station and don't want to move your clients to a UV station and want to cure the gel at the the station where you work or move it to a station next to you.<br /><br />The Royal UV lamp has an &#34;on demand fan&#34; to dry your clients' nails polish before applying the UV gel for curing without activating the UV lights, this avoid your clients from unnecessary exposure to ultra violet (UV) light.<br /><br />The Royal and the Ikonna has 5 minutes limit timer which is fine if you have a fixed curing time. However, with the Royal you have the option of keeping the UV bulbs to stay on until you deactivate it. This helps tremendously for those who works with liquid gel (builder gel or special art works involved liquid color gel).<br /><br />&#60;&#62;&#60;&#62; --&#62; ONE IMPROVEMENT FOR THE ROYAL UV LAMP IS TO PUT THE VENT(S) ON THE SIDES TO PREVENT THE LIGHT FROM EXPOSING TO THE GEL AS IT IS BEING APPLIED. &#60;-- &#60;&#62;&#60;&#62;<br /><br />I would recommend this product to all nails tech.   1393. I recently purchased the Anti UV gloves as an alternative to putting sunscreen on my hands before using the UV lamp. I am not a nail technician, but I do my own gel nails at home using a UV lamp, probably every two weeks when I change my polish. Although my hands go under the lamp for short periods of time, I still want to keep the majority of my skin covered. The gloves are definitely the way to go, in terms of time and comfort. It eliminates having to take the step of removing any suncreen residue from the nails and surrounding nailbeds, and my hands aren't left feeling sticky or oily from the lotion. They fit well, easy to take on and off and they do not interfer with polishing the nails. There is enough room between the glove end and the nail so nothing could get smudged.   1406. I LOVE this dryer!!! I need to tell you though, I was a little afraid it didn't work at first. I used the dryer for the 180 second timeframe after applying the gel base, I touched my nails before applying the first color coat to make sure they were dry and my nails were sticky/not dry. I did another cycle for 180 seconds with the same result. At this point I was so frustrated I just continued painting my nails and curing in between. After I put the top coat on and used the dryer for the 240 second timeframe twice, my nails were STILL STICKY. So I took my nail Polish remover on a Cotten ball and tried to take off the color. After I did that, my nails were perfect!!! And DRY!!! So don't be alarmed by the &#34;stickyness&#34; just continue painting and curing until the end!!! Good luck!

  1452. Purchased specifically to cure CND shellac and it does a tremendous job with CND shellac. Complaints you see about shellac not drying are due to users not completing the final step in the CND shellac process which is wiping the nails with alcohol after the final cure. This removes the sticky residue that they interpret as the nails not being dry. I am completely happy with this dryer and would definitely recommend.

You can use Shellac, Gellish and regular polish as well in this unit. I was able to cut my nail time in half with this dryer. I had a smaller unit that only would do one had at a time and took a full 2 minutes to cure each segment first the foundation then the 2 coats of color then the top coat and only one hand at a time. I typically use the Gellish and it takes 90 seconds and it is cured both hands at once. I love that it is big enough to cure my thumbs to as with my other dryer the foundation and topcoat would run to the side and get thick on the edges not with this dryer.<br /><br />I don't usually polish my toes because I tend to chip or smear them while drying with this I can polish and dry for 120 seconds just to make sure and I am good to go drying again both feet at one time. It is quiet and quick.<br /><br />The only thing that I found is I had to find a new place to store it as it is larger and does not fit in my nail kit carrier that I have but it is so worth the money and easy to use. It is so easy to install the bulbs and plug in and good to go.<br /><br />I can't say enough I love this dryer it is professional grade with the easy of using at home.<br />[[ASIN:B006IBM21K 54 WATT ROYAL NAILS PROFESSIONAL UV LIGHT GEL AND ACRILIC NAIL DRYER & CURING RN541 WORKS WITH CND, SHELLAC, OPI, HARMONY GELLISH, IBD GELAC, ETC.. FOR DOUBLE. HANDS OR FEET.]]

So I know from watching the ladies at the shop that the UV lamp is very important. The better the gel dries the longer my nails would last. I read so many reviews about these UV lamps and after reading the positive reviews on the 54 Watt Royal Nails Professional UV light I decided to try it. I am SO glad I did too! It works great!!! The lightbulbs are so easy to put in which I read the others had so many issues with. It was the EASIEST thing to do. Just pop in the lightbulbs, plug it in and turn on the switch. It is well with the price and not only does it work for gel nails I was able to do my sisters nails with regular polish and it dried in minutes! It has several timers 5 I believe(90,120,180,240,300 min AND a built in fan)and is so spacious that you can fit both hands and feet if your doing your own pedicure. I also liked the convenience of being able to fix my own nails because we all know to go back and fix just one nail is a pain! I have never left a review before but I hoped that I could help someone make their decison a bit easier if your on the fence on which dryer you will purchase.   1482. I purchased this product after doing quite a bit of research online about the gel manicure systems. I discovered that the nail polish manufactures have designed the gel polishes to be system specific, meaning an opi polish has a specific cure time and may need an LED light to cure as apposed to an UV light. Same with gelish, etc... I purchased several of the OPI gel polishes as I had read that these could be cured with an UV light but it would take a little longer. This system was advertised to work for OPI and others so i figured it would be a good system to have, allowing more options for polish colors from different companies. The lamp turns on and the fan on the unit works. However, one of the bulbs was broken when I received it (I guess you could expect something like this, being that it was shipped). My major issue with it is that it wont cure the gel polishes, even after keeping my hands in the system for about 10 minutes for each of the layers, base, polish X 2 and top coat. It will partially cure some of the colors, allowing me to rub the color right off my nails. I tried another brand of gel polish and the same thing happened. So frustrating! Now I am looking at buying an OPI system, which is what I should have done from the start.

  1580. If you are considering buying an UV lamp, think no further. This is a full 54 Watt professional nail dryer that you can use on natural and fake nails - not just limited to gels and acrylics. Get a UV topcoat (I use Seche Ultra-V) and YOU CAN CURE REGULAR NAIL POLISH (with UV topcoat). A large majority of lamps are 36 watts (4 - 9 watt bulbs), this dryer comes with 6 bulbs for 54W. Easily accommodates both hands or feet. Timer has 60 second increments up to 5 minutes, and a fan that is optional for use. It is a super bargain at this price. The only drawback is that it's not really convenient for travel, it can be transported but it's not convenient.

Then at the end, I used the rubbing alcohol as suggested and all the &#34;stickiness&#34; was gone and my nails were smooth and dry. I could do anything right away. I highly recommend this unit!
